EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance



The City of Modesto - WWTP, Jennings Plant is a secondary treatment plant for wastewater from domestic and industrial sources. The primary wastewater treatment plant design has conventional primary treatment which screens coarse materials, removes grit and floatable organic solids and provides primary clarification.  

Conventional secondary treatment at the Jennings Plant removes soluble organic material and additional suspended organic solids. There is a solid handling system with dissolved flotation thickening of the secondary waste water for algae removal. 

The effluent leaving the secondary WWTP contains biological organics. Some of these may be pathogenic (disease causing) organisms. The effluent is disinfected to protect the public health by the use of a chlorine solution provided at the plant by mixing chlorine gas and water. The chlorine contact basin provides retention time for the chlorine to disinfect the treated wastewater. Disinfection of the wastewater is performed prior to discharge to river disposal.

Some residual chlorine is present after disinfection and represents a toxic hazard. The chlorine is neutralized to remove this threat by the addition of sulfur dioxide, i.e., dechlorination of the wastewater is performed prior to discharge to river disposal. The Facility employs a chlorination system for final effluent disinfection using chlorine gas and a dechlorination facility utilizing sulfur dioxide. 



Accidental Release Prevention Policies



The City of Modesto - WWTP, Jennings Plant has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Chlorination and Dechlorination processes. The City of Modesto's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated su

bstance.



Hazard Assessment Summary and Offsite Consequence Analysis



Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for each the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  



Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary    

Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one alternative release scenario has been defined for both the chlorine and sulfur dioxide processes. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.

  

Risk Considerations

Although the storage and use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide has inherent potential risks and the release scenarios can potentially reach sensitive populations within the community, the City of Modesto-WWTP, Jennings Plant has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible. In addition it should be noted that there are embedded analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a chlorine and sulfur dioxide release, including the following: 

?    The facility's chlorine and sulfur dioxide tanks are located in enclosed buildings.

?    The chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems' level instrumentation include an audible/visual alarm, as well as a direct SCADA alarm that automatically alarm in  the River Discharge Station, the Lab Building at the Jennings Plant, and the Main Office at the Sutter Plant.

   

Accidental Release Prevention Program



As part of the implementation of CalARP Program 3, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by the City of

Modesto-WWTP, Jennings Plant to manage process safety issues associated with the use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed. 





Five-Year Accident History



There have been no CalARP applicable accidental release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide in the last five years.



Emergency Response Program



The City of Modesto - WWTP, Jennings Plant facility is a first responding facility in the event of an emergency and therefore has developed and implemented an Emergency Response Plan.  As part of the facility's emergency response effort it maintains a HAZMAT trailer that includes emergency equipment applicable for response activities.  Facility personnel involved with emergency response activities go through annual training as applicable to their duties and responsibilities under the Plan. 



Planned Changes To Improve Safety



Several studies have been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility. These studies include the following: Process Hazard Analysis and the Seismic Assessment. Any outstanding recommendations from these studies will be completed in a timely manner.



External Events Assessment



Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section ?2745.7(l), general events external to the facility that can conceivably cause a release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide were addressed by the April 10th 2013 Process Hazard Analysis for the chlorination and dechlorination processes.  Specifically, the external events requirements were met with the following actions:

Description of the types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA Section 2760.2 or Hazard Review Section 2755.2.  

?    During the Process Hazard Analysis, a broad list of external events was considered by the Team. However, the Team only deemed some of these events as bein

g credible, and fully developed those scenarios that present an opportunity for chemical release.  

The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered. If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.

?    Seismic events were deemed a potential threat to the system given the location of the facility. Therefore, seismic restraints were designed into the system components to ensure they would be capable of withstanding any potential seismic events. Specific equipment restraints and calculations are provided in the Seismic Assessment section of the program binder.

?    The magnitude of the external events considered is detailed within the Process Hazard Analysis Worksheets.

For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint off-site, apply  

- The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA;

- Major hazards identified;

- Process controls in use;

- Mitigation systems in use;

- Monitoring and detection systems in use; and,

- Changes since the last Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).

?    The recommendations precipitating from the Process Hazard Analysis are summarized in Attachment B: Recommendations in the "Process Hazard Analysis" report.  All recommendations are documented, provided with a column that allows designation of a date of a completion, and description of the action required.



Flammables Worst and Alternative Cases



The use of flammable materials at City of Modesto WWTP, Jennings Plant is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements. Therefore this section is not applicable.



Seismic Assessment



A seismic safety walk-down was completed in November 2012 to assess the seismi

c vulnerability of the process equipment that contain significant quantities of chlorine and sulfur dioxide at the facility and issue recommendations for the correction of any seismic deficiencies observed for any such equipment or their support structures. The equipment seismic support systems and equipment can be found behind the Seismic Assessment tab in the report binder.
